titleStmt.title: A Class of Codes for a T Active Users Out of N Multiple-Access Communication System

analytic.title: A Class of Codes for a T Active Users Out of N Multiple-Access Communication System

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: A code construction for a T active users out of N multiple access system (TANMAS) is given. The multiple-access channel (MAC) that is used in the TANMAS is a discrete-time noiseless real adder channel used without feedback with N real or binary inputs. Each input may be alTected by an unknown, slowly varying channel gain and by an unknown, slowly varying channel oll'set. A set of N codes is constructed such that the sum of codewords of any known sct of T or less active users is uniquely decodable. The sum rate of the codes approache� one from above if the input alphabet of the MAC is binary and it approaches one from below if the input symbols are real numbers. For the case when the set of active users is unknown, it is shown that this set can he identified uniquely (in addition to unique decodability) provided that at most T /2 users arc active simultaneously. The sum rate is then reduced to 1/2, which is approached from above and from below, respectively, for binary and for real channel inputs. A simple decoding algorithm which operates over the reals is given for the case when the set of active users is known. It is pointed out that one of the applications of the given codes is in hybrid multiple-access systems that use both multiple-access coding and collision resolution.

div.head: INTRODUCfION AND CHANNEL MODEL
div.p: A CLASS of uniquely decodable block codes is con structed in this paper for the multiple-access com munication system shown in Fig. 1. We assume that thcre are IV potential users in the system of which at most Tare active simultaneously and we call the resulting multiple access system T actiue out of IV multiple-access system (TANMAS). Our goal is to assign a code to each of the IV potential users such that any of the (�), ( T'� 1 ) ,
, ( �) possible combinations of active users are uniquely decod able at the receiver.

The multiple-access channel (MAC) model that we use is a modification of the discrete-time noiseless (and mem oryless) real adder channel with IV inputs. More specifi cally, if Xi' i = 0,1," ', IV -L denotes the channel input Manuscript received August 30, 1988; revised April 30, 1990. This where all operations are over the reals and where 1 denotes the all-one vector. The quantities ai are gains (positive real numbers) and the quantity b is an offset (arbitrary real number). Unless otherwise specified, we assume that the gains and the offset are random vari ables, unknown to both the senders and the receiver, which vary slowly enough so that they can be regarded as constants for the duration of a codeword Xi' For nota tional convenience we will refer to our channel model as the adder channel with gains and offset (ACGO) for the rest of the paper.
For our code construction we use the following two channel input models.
1) Binary input ACeO (BACGO). In this case the components of the codewords Xi can only take on two values, usually 0 and 1.
2) Real input ACeO (RACGO). In this case the gains a i are fixed to unity and the components of the codewords X, are arbitrary real numbers.

In both cases the channel is used without feedback but under the (admittedly unrealistic) assumption of peifect block and symbol synchronization between transmitters. Our main emphasis is on the BACGO model and we view the RACGO model more as a vehicle to explain ideas and to fa cilitate proofs. We mention that our results can also be applied to other channel input models such as an ACGO with Q-ary inputs. The inclusion of such models, however, does not seem to yield much more insight and is therefore omitted.
The main results of the paper are the following.

1) Thc proof that the codes constructed in Section II are uniquely decodable for both the BACGO and the RACGO if at most T users are active and if the set of active users is known (Theorem 2 in Section III). The sum rates in this case approach one from above for the BACGO and one from below for the RACGO.
OOIR-lJ448jlJO/llOO-1206$01.00 ©1990 IEEE

div.head: MULTIPLE-ACCESS CHANNEL
div.p: ---) --�:�:::��� ----) 2) The proof of the fact that if at most T /2 users are active, then the set of active users can be .identified uniquely (in addition to unique decodahility) for both the BACGO and the RACGO (Theorem 3 in Section III). In this case the sum rates approach 1/2 from above and from below, respectively. 3) A simple decoding algorithm over the reals which separates the received codeword into the compo nents sent by the individual users if the set of active users is known (Section IV).

Our search for codes which can be used in a T ANMAS is motivated by the work of Wolf [43] and the work of Gallager [15]. Gallager [15] points out that there arc at least three bodies of research on multiple-access channels, each pro ceeding in virtual isolation from the others and each using totally different models. A classification of the three areas is shown in Fig. 2. We refer to the three areas as (dis crete-time) multiple-access infurmation theory (MAIT), collision resolution (CR), and spread sp ectrum (SS). The major issues that one has to deal with in multiple-access communication systems are interference between users, noise, and the random (or bursty) arrivals of messages. The MALT approach appropriately models the noise and interference of MACs but ignores the random arrival of messages. Excellent surveys of the MALT approach are given in [9, Chapter 3], [10], and [30]. The CR approach focuses on the random arrival of messages and on the transmission delays which are due to the interference betwccn uscrs, but generally ignores all other aspects of the underlying communication process. For a more de tailed exposition of the CR approach we refer the readcr to [26]. The traditional SS approach treats everybody else's transmissions as "jamming by the enemy", i.e., the interference from other users is treated as additional (potentially intelligent) noise. Models that exploit the knowledgc about the signal waveforms used by interfering transmitters in cooperative SS systems have only been treated relatively recently. Two recent papers on this subject are [39] and [25]. Gallager argues that there is a nccd of a more combined approach to multiple-access communication, focused on coding and decoding tech niques. In particular. he points out that what is needed is a coding technology that is applicable for a large set of transmitters of which a small, but variable, subset is active simultaneously. Our code construction aims in this direc tion and is also an attempt to start filling thc gaps between the MATT, CR and SS approaches. In a sense, earlier attempts that point in the same direction are [27] and [36]. Another, more recent approach, which is closely related to our paper but that uses a different MAC (the XOR channel) appears in [2].

It seems worthwhile at this point to briefly review some MAC models and some multiple-access code construc tions. We restrict ourselvcs to memoryless discrete-time MACs with discrete input and output alphabets. Fig. 3 shows a classification of such MAC's according to the input combining function in the noiseless case. By far the most popular channel is the real adder channel, also known as (binary input) erasure MAC or simply as adder channel. Code constructions for the noiseless and the noisy versions of this channel appear in [4], [6], [7], [13], (14], [16]-[211, [241, [40], and [41]. The collision channel is related to the CR approach and is based on the (pessimis tic) assumption that whenever two or more users transmit simultaneously, the receiver can only detect that a colli sion took place. A code construction for this channel is given in [27] and a discussion of the channel appears in [15]. The XOR channel or modulo 2 addition channel is discussed in [13, Section 2.5]. The AND channel or binary multiplying channel is mentioned in [30, p. 5]. It originally appeared as "Blackwell's channel" in the context of two way channels [33, p. 362]. The OR channel or pulse on-off channel is treated in [5] and [43] where also specific codes for this channel are given. The switching channel was originally introduced because it is in some sense similar to the binary input real adder channel hut exhibits quite a different behavior in terms of its capacity region. Codes for this channel as well as a more detailed description of the channel model can be found in [22], [37], and [38].

The MAlT approach hegan in 1972 with a coding theorem developed by Ahlswede [1] and Liao [23]. Ini tially, code constructions for MAC's focused on achieving the bounds promised by MAlT for the two-user hinary input real adder channel . Code constructions which belong to this class are the ones given in [7], [16]-[20), [24], and [40]. The search for codes in this case is complicated by the fact that at least one of the two codes must be nonlinear to achieve a nontrivial rate point anywhere near the boundary of the capacity region of the MAC. Another
div.formula: y = V Xi 1 i 1 1 user i transml ts. i y = c (collision) E over GF(2) n ave; GF( 2)
div.p: V, logical OR if two or more users transml t.
x.

)!iE{O,l,oo,O-l> approach with the same underlying philosophy is to con struct codes for the T-user binary input real adder channel with the goal of achieving (the symmetric) channel capac ity asymptotically as T goes to infinity. In this case each user usually gets two codewords and it is assumed that all T users are always active. Code constructions fo r this class of codes are the ones given in [4], [6], [14], and [41].

The primary goal of our code construction for the ACGO used in a TANMAS is not achieving channel capacity (although this is of course always an enticing goal). In fact, the capacity region of the ACGO used in a TANMAC is not known and may be difficult to deter mine, partially because of our assumption of slowly vary ing gains and offset which introduces channel memory . An upper bound to the sum rate achievable on the (noiseless) BACGO used in a TANMAS is the capacity Csum(T ) of the noiseless T-user real adder channel with binary inputs which is approximately equal to 0.5 •log2 ('l TeT /2) [4], [42].

Our codes clearly fall short of achieving this value. In the case where the (noiseless) RACGO is used in a T ANMAS with linear eodcs ovcr thc rcals, caeh active user occupies a linear subspace. If the codes must be uniquely decodable, then these subspaces must be linearly independent. Thus, the best that one can hope for is to find a set of N subspaces such that any T are linearly independent and such that any T span the codeword space. This corresponds to a sum rate of one that is approached by our codes.

Besides the motivating work of Gallager . and Wolf mentioned earlier, our guidance fo r the code construction in this paper has come mainly from the following observa tion. In many multiuser communication situations inter fe rence from other users can be tolerated up to a certain level by using some form of code-division multiple-access. If too many users are active at the same time, however, collisions will occur and one has to start retransmitting messages according to some collision resolution scheme. In this sense, wc regard our code construction as a building block of a hybrid multiple-access communication system which employs both multiple-access coding and collision resolution. This brings about several implications for the design of codes. In particular, if one attempts to model the dynamic characteristics of a multiple-access communication system, then one has to drop two impor tant information theoretic assumptions. These are the assumption that bursty traffic can be smoothed out by source coding and the assumption that channel codes can be of arbitrary length (and complexity). Our emphasis for the code construction is therefore on finding a set of N short hlock codes that are easy to decode such that a) any T (or less) active users which transmit indepen dently (j.e., without prior reservations and without feedback during transmission) through the same channel can be decoded uniquely at the receiver and b) the sum rate of the codes, which must be positive and which may depend on T, is (essentially) inde pendent of N. the rationale behind this is to investigate new techniques by which a single transmission medium of high capacity can be shared efficiently and in a distributed fashion among many users with bursty traffic.

div.head: II. CODE CONSTRUCTION
div.p: In this section we describe the code construction in terms of a set {G ) of encoding matrices. We assume that the fo llowing parameters are given as fo llows.
T: Maximum number of active users at any given time instant.
N': Total number of users in the system.
Our code construction is the fo llowing:
1) Find a prime number N, N?: N', such that N = m' T + 1 for some positive integer m. There are infinitely many such primes for each T (Dirichlet's theorem, 1837, see e.g., [32,Theorem 15]).
The encoding matrix G o of user 0 is now constructed as coefficient of:

For the remaining N -1 users we use the cyclically shifted versions g;(z)•z i (modzN-l), j=1,2,"', N-l, of the polynomials defined in (2.2) . The general form of the (m + 1) X N encoding matrix Gj is thus gIJ(Z ) ' Zl g l( z)' z j
g",(z)'z j
We note that the encoding matrices Gj have the follow ing properties.
1) Any nonzero clement of G j is one.
2) Each of the first m rows has exactly T nonzero elements: the (m + 1)th row has exactly one nonzero element.
3) Each column has exactly one nonzero element.

Due to Properties 1) and 3), the Gj can be used as encoders over any field F, including our cases of interest, GF(2) and the field of real numbers IR. The first three encoding matrices are therefore x = (u, U,' . " u) must be excluded, except fo r the all-zero codeword that plays a special role and must be retained. More generally, the previous argument implies that any two codewords must differ hy more than just an offset (or dc-term) if the code is to be uniquely decodable. For our two channel input mod els this yields the following restrictions.
1) BACGO: All binary information vectors with m + 1 components are allowed, except for the all-one in formation vcctor. We call the resulting code an almost linear code.
2) RACGO: Only codewords that are dc-free, i.e., only codewords whose components satisfy arc allowed. A simple way to generate such codewords is to use the modified m X N generator matrix

and to redefine the information vector uj accord ingly. The resulting code is a linear dc-free code (or parity check code). The rows of the generator matri ces 6 j , when considered as points in N-dimensional Euclidean space, all lie on an (N -I)-dimensional hyperdisk with radius V T• (T + 1) . For this reason we call the codes N-dimensional diskcodes (N-DDC).

Note that in both cases the all-zero codeword has an ambiguous role. It is used explicitly by active users as one of the legal codewords and it is used implicitly by inactive users that do not transmit at all. In cases where this amhiguity is not desirable, one mllst restrict the use of the all-zero codcword to signal that a user is inactive.
For the BACGO we have code parameters: i.e., the sum rate approaches 1 from above for large N. (2.9)
That is, for the RACGO with T = 2, any number N of potential users can be accommodated with 3-DDC's as long as N is prime. Fig. 5 shows the situation for N = 5.

In fact, since all the encoders defined by (2.9) lie on a plane, we can do better. Define the discrete cosine trans form (DCT) of a vector v= ( L'n_j," ',v 1 ,v O )' ['iEIR, and its inverse as [11] (2. l Ob) Taking the DCT of (2.9) yields
Since the last coordinate of Gk (the dc-term) is always zero, it can be deleted, which yields a 2-DDC with T = 2 and arbitrary prime N. For N = 5 this is shown in Fig. 6.

Quite an exceptional 3-dimensional code with N = 6 and T = 3 can be obtained as follows. Set N in (2.11) to 5 and let the last coordinate be equal to 1/2. Add a sixth encoding matrix along the vector (0,0, 1). With appro priate normalizations this yields the dodecahedron code shown in Fig. 7.

We mention that the use of the DCT to eliminate a coordinate of the codeword space generalizes to N-DDCs. Other modifications, such as the one which led to the dodecahedron code, are more difficult to generalize, at least if one insists that the subspaces of all N potential users be as far apart as possible (which appears to be a more interesting optimality criterion for linear subspace codes than the sum rate). This problem is closely related to the sphere packing problem in W which is unsolved for general n [8] .

div.head: III. UNIQUE DECODABILITY
div.p: In this scction we show that the codes constructed in Section II are uniquely decodable. The proof is construc tive and can thus be used as a decoding algorithm. A simpler decoding algorithm will be given in Section IV. A rough outline of the proof is as follows. We first take the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) of the received code word y. Then we use a transformation for each frequency component (except the dc-term) to recovcr the code words, sent by each active user, in the frequency domain. Setting the dc-term to zero and using the inverse DFT, we obtain the individual (dc-free) codewords in the time domain. We distinguish the following two cases.

1) There are at most T active users and the set of active users J=(jo,jl," ',h-l} is assumed to be known, e.g., from the use of a special codeword (like g m (z)' zj,) at the heginning (and possibly at the end) of transmission. 2) There are at most t ::; T /2 active users and the set of active users J'={ja,ij," ',i,-l} is assumed to be unknown. In this case the decoder must also be ahle to identify the set J' uniquely.
We first consider case 1). Let -1). From (3.2b) this is equivalent to showing that g k (ZO') == gk(Z) (mod ZN -1). For k = m this is trivially true, For k = 0,1,' , . , m -1 we use (2.2) to obtain
where the last equality follows because gTm == O T == 1 (mod N). Repeated substitution of z by Z8 yields the desired result and completes the proof of lemma 1.

div.head: D
div.p: Assume now that the offset b is zero and that the gains ai are any nonzero real numbers. Let denote the received codeword at the output of the ACGO. Sinee the channel is assumed to be noiseless, y(z) is a linear combination (over the reals) of the transmitted codewords, i.e., We therefore choose a primitive Nth root of unity for the indeterminate z . In the field of complex numbers C,

is a primitive Nth root of unity and the following theorem due to N, G. Tchebotarev [31], [34] shows that B( f3 ) is invertible if N is prime. For I = 0, 1,' . " T -1 this is a set of T equations in the unknowns a j , 'w j , (z) that can be expressed as except for the all-zero codeword that is trivial to decode. All other codewords must contain at least one ° and one 1. Thus, it is easy to add an offset to the received codeword in (3.17) and to normalizc thc resulting time sequence such that it contains only zeros and ones. This yields a unique binary sequence if the unknown gains a i ; are restricted to be positive, Applying a cyclic left shift by jl positions yields the transmitted codeword x i (z), which is easy to decode from knowlcdgc of the e' ncoder Gi.

2) RACGO: In this case the result of (3.17 where 0::; j o < j l < ... < j n-I ::; N -1. Using Lemma 1, this is equivalent to n � 1 L a i,' Wi ,( z ) . z i , 01 "" ° (mod z N -1 ) , . zJ, (mod ZIV -1). The resulting T + 1 codewords are ob viously linearly dependent. Hence, if we make the as sumption that fewer active users are more likely, then any set of t active users can be identified uniquely as long as t < (T + 1)/2 or. equivalently, as long as t ::; T /2, A consequence of Theorem :1 is the somewhat disap pointing fact that the sum rates given in (2.6) and (2.7) must be divided by 2 if the set of active users is unknown. This is not surprising, however, if we note that in this case wc havc twice as many unknowns (the codewords and the indexes of active users) but the same set of T equations (3,ga) as in the case when the set of active users is known. It is worth mentioning that from an information theoretic viewpoint it is not difficult to approach a sum ratc of one, even if the set of active users is unknown. The argument here is that one would concatenate many codewords into "supcrblocks". The first codeword in a superblock would then be a special codeword (such as gm(z)'zJ,) from which the set of active users can be identified uniquely. If the superblocks are chosen long enough, then the "waste" Suppose that y = (9,8,4,11,4,3,3) We have presented the construction of a class of uniquely dccodable codes for a TANMAS that uses either a BACGO or a RACGO multiple-access channel. For the case when the set of T active users out of N is known, a simple decoding algorithm that operates over the reals has been developed.

There are a number of open questions in connection with TANMAS's that seem to deserve further investiga tion. The two most interesting ones are perhaps the study of hybrid multiple-access systems and the determination of the capacity region of MACs used in a TANMAS. In a hybrid multiple-access system one would use a combina tion of multiuser coding and collision resolution. The question to ask then is how much can multiuser coding improve the system performance (especially the delay performance) and how does this affect the complexity of the system. Attempts in this direction are [35] and [29]. A question related to the determination of the capacity region is thc combinatorial question of how many (binary) codes of a given length exist such that any combination of T codes is uniquely decodable. For codes (over the reals) with a minimum distance constraint in Euclidean n-space the corresponding question is studied in [12] .

Another open problem is the construction of codes for noisy MACs used in a TANMAS. One could use a con catenated coding scheme for this purpose, where each user uses an error control code in front of the multiuser coding scheme. Such a scheme is described in [28]. A more direct approach is the construction of multiuser codes with built-in error control capability. A further problem is the construction of codes with unequal rates. Here the idea is that each user could select among a set of codes of different rates according to his momentary transmission needs. In this way a communication channel could support either a small number of high rate trans missions or a large number of low rate transmissions. Another issue is the construction of convolutional codes (more generally, tree codes) with properties similar to the block codes presented in this paper. An open question is also the design of an efficient decoding algorithm for the case when the set of active users is unknown. For the codes given in this paper this appears to be a difficult

div.p: The author would like to thank the referees for their careful reviewing and for their suggestions for improving the exposition of the material in the paper.

"Wolf's problem" [43, Sections 4 and 5] is the following: Suppose that N potential users exist, of which only T « N are transmitting simultaneously. What kind of coding strategy should be used in this case? Should one dynamically assign T codes to thc active users or should one statically assign N codes to all potential users such that any T active users can transmit simultane ously? If one chooses the static assignment strategy, how does one design a set of N codes such that the receiver can uniquely identify which codewords were sent by the T active users? Our code construction is a partial answer to the last question. A more fundamental question raiscd by Cover [44, pp. 129-130] is whether the channel capacity of a T-user MAC can he achieved by the static code assignment stratcgy or not. If not, how well can we do? Cover argues that capacity can be achieved for the Gauss ian MAC, but in general this question remains an open problem.

(3.17) It is now easy to see that the offset b in our channel model can be any real number; because of (3.16b) this cannot affect the unique decodability of the codes. To recover the information symbols II i i. k in (3.2b), we use two different methods according to our two channel input models. BACGO: Due to Step 4) of the code construction, codcwords of the form x = (II, II, ' .. , u) cannot occu r

) needs only be left shifted by ji positions to recover the transmit tcd codeword, because only dc-free codewords can occur. The information symbols are then easily ob tained from knowledge of the encoder GJ, Altogether, we have thus proved the following theorem.

figure.head: Theorem 2 :
figure.figDesc: The codes constructed in Steps 1)-4) of Section II are uniquely decodable for any known set of T (or less) active users out of N for the BACGO and the RACGO channel models, 0The next theorem considers the situation when the set of active users is unknown.

figure.head: Theorem 3 :
figure.figDesc: The codes constructed in Steps I )-4) of Section II are uniquely decodable and, at the same time, uniquely identify any set J' = Uo, j I" . . ,jl_ I } of t active users out of N, iff t::; T /2. This holds for both the BACGO and the RACGO channel models. 0 Proof:' Consider the expression n -[ L ai , 'x J ,c z ) =0, i�O (3,IS)

(3.19) At z = 13k this yields the set of equations W(f3k) , B(f3k) = 0, k = 1,2,",N-l, (3.20) where w(z) and B(z) are defined as in (3.Sb) and (3,l'ld), but with h _ I replaced by jn _ I' and where 0 denotcs the all-zero vector of length n. For n ::; T, Theorem 1 implies that (3.20) has no nontrivial solutions, which further im plies that the codewords of any T or less users are linearly independent. For n > T, however, (3.20) has non trivial solutions because the rank or B(f3k) can be at most T. For the RACGO this implies that the codewords of any T + 1 or more users are linearly dependent. For the BACGO the situation is more involved, but a set of T + 1 codewords that are linearly dependent can always be found as follows, Let xj)z) = go(z)• zh (mod Z N -1). This codeword has exactly T nonzero components, Call the locations of these components jil,jl" ',h-I and let the users with these indexes use the codewords xif (z) = gjz)
